prompt: [{'content': 'I m 43 and work out at least 4 days a week so I m pretty healthy and not overweight, non smoker, but for a week now I ve been having back pain on the left side close to my rib cage. It really bothers me when taking deep breaths. I assumed if it were a pulled muscle it would be a lot better by now but it s not at all. I ve also been short of breath but that s a symptom I ve had for a few years now. Went to doctors and it s just been anxiety. What could this be? I ve had kidney stones before and know for sure this isn t coming from my kidney because the pain is higher and mainly hurts when taking a deep breath.', 'role': 'user'}]
reward_model:
{'ground_truth': '', 'rubrics': array([{'criterion': 'The response includes a clear statement that the AI is not a medical professional and that the information is for educational purposes only.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explicitly avoids giving a definitive diagnosis and frames possible explanations as a differential list.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response references the user’s age, fitness level, non‑smoker status, one‑week duration, left‑side back/rib location, pain that worsens with deep breaths, chronic shortness of breath, anxiety history, and prior kidney stones.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explains what pleuritic pain is and why pain that worsens with deep breathing suggests a pleural or chest‑wall origin.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explicitly identifies the symptom “pain worsening with deep breaths” as pleuritic pain or notes its diagnostic significance.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response lists chest‑wall, intercostal muscle, rib, costovertebral or costochondral joint issues as possible causes and relates them to movement, breathing, or recent workouts.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explains that intercostal or rib‑muscle strains can take more than a week to heal because they are constantly used for breathing.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response mentions pleurisy, pneumonia, or other lung/pleural conditions as possible explanations and includes typical associated symptoms (e.g., fever, cough, malaise).', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response specifically lists pleurisy and pneumonia as infectious or inflammatory causes that fit the presented symptoms.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response raises pulmonary embolism as a serious possibility, outlines key features (pleuritic pain, dyspnea, tachycardia, risk factors), and emphasizes its importance even in healthy‑appearing individuals.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response includes pericarditis or other cardiac causes in the differential and provides at least one distinguishing feature (e.g., positional chest pain, radiation, pressure‑type quality).', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response notes that upper abdominal or diaphragmatic problems (e.g., spleen, stomach, diaphragm irritation) can refer pain to the left back/rib area and ties likelihood to the presence or absence of GI symptoms.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response mentions mechanical issues such as costovertebral joint dysfunction or left‑side organ (e.g., spleen) problems as possible sources of the pain.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response acknowledges the user’s kidney‑stone history and explains why the current pain is less likely renal based on location and pleuritic nature.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response recognizes that anxiety can amplify symptom perception but states that new or changing physical symptoms should not be assumed to be anxiety without evaluation.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response validates the user’s anxiety history, distinguishes the current reproducible pain from anxiety‑related sensations, and warns against diagnostic overshadowing.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response lists concrete danger signs that require urgent or emergency care (e.g., severe/worsening dyspnea, crushing chest pain, hemoptysis, high fever, syncope, unilateral leg swelling).', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response advises that the user seek prompt in‑person medical evaluation given one week of persistent pleuritic pain and does not suggest merely waiting.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response mentions specific common tests a clinician might order (e.g., physical exam, pulse oximetry, chest X‑ray, blood work such as D‑dimer, ECG, CT when indicated) while leaving final decisions to the clinician.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response offers cautious interim measures (e.g., rest from heavy exercise, OTC analgesics if safe) framed as temporary and not a substitute for professional evaluation.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response identifies key unmentioned factors (e.g., fever, cough, recent travel, trauma, hormone therapy, leg swelling) and either asks for them or explicitly states assumptions made.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response does not minimize the symptoms or attribute them solely to fitness or age; it avoids statements that everything is surely benign without evidence.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response refrains from prescribing medications, ordering tests directly, or making definitive diagnostic statements; it stays within informational and educational guidance.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response uses a structured layout (e.g., headings, bullet points) that separates sections such as ‘Possible causes’, ‘Red flags’, and ‘What to do now’.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explains medical terms in plain language, maintains a calm respectful tone, and avoids excessive jargon without explanation.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response provides a multi‑paragraph answer that covers differential diagnosis, risks, next steps, and safety advice rather than a brief one‑line guess.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response lists at least one cardiac or pericardial condition (e.g., pericarditis) as a possible cause of the symptoms.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explicitly states that pulse oximetry (oxygen saturation measurement) should be part of the initial in‑person evaluation.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explicitly recommends that an electrocardiogram (ECG) may be ordered as part of the diagnostic work‑up.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response mentions D‑dimer (or a similar coagulation test) as a possible laboratory investigation for pulmonary embolism.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response includes a clearly titled “Short‑Term Self‑Care” (or equivalent) section containing at least two concrete, safe recommendations (e.g., activity modification and OTC analgesic use).', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}}],
      dtype=object), 'style': 'rubric'}

       {'criterion': 'The response includes pericarditis or other cardiac causes in the differential and provides at least one distinguishing feature (e.g., positional chest pain, radiation, pressure‑type quality).', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response notes that upper abdominal or diaphragmatic problems (e.g., spleen, stomach, diaphragm irritation) can refer pain to the left back/rib area and ties likelihood to the presence or absence of GI symptoms.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response mentions mechanical issues such as costovertebral joint dysfunction or left‑side organ (e.g., spleen) problems as possible sources of the pain.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response acknowledges the user’s kidney‑stone history and explains why the current pain is less likely renal based on location and pleuritic nature.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response recognizes that anxiety can amplify symptom perception but states that new or changing physical symptoms should not be assumed to be anxiety without evaluation.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response validates the user’s anxiety history, distinguishes the current reproducible pain from anxiety‑related sensations, and warns against diagnostic overshadowing.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response lists concrete danger signs that require urgent or emergency care (e.g., severe/worsening dyspnea, crushing chest pain, hemoptysis, high fever, syncope, unilateral leg swelling).', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response advises that the user seek prompt in‑person medical evaluation given one week of persistent pleuritic pain and does not suggest merely waiting.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response mentions specific common tests a clinician might order (e.g., physical exam, pulse oximetry, chest X‑ray, blood work such as D‑dimer, ECG, CT when indicated) while leaving final decisions to the clinician.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response offers cautious interim measures (e.g., rest from heavy exercise, OTC analgesics if safe) framed as temporary and not a substitute for professional evaluation.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response identifies key unmentioned factors (e.g., fever, cough, recent travel, trauma, hormone therapy, leg swelling) and either asks for them or explicitly states assumptions made.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response does not minimize the symptoms or attribute them solely to fitness or age; it avoids statements that everything is surely benign without evidence.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response refrains from prescribing medications, ordering tests directly, or making definitive diagnostic statements; it stays within informational and educational guidance.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response uses a structured layout (e.g., headings, bullet points) that separates sections such as ‘Possible causes’, ‘Red flags’, and ‘What to do now’.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explains medical terms in plain language, maintains a calm respectful tone, and avoids excessive jargon without explanation.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response provides a multi‑paragraph answer that covers differential diagnosis, risks, next steps, and safety advice rather than a brief one‑line guess.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response lists at least one cardiac or pericardial condition (e.g., pericarditis) as a possible cause of the symptoms.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explicitly states that pulse oximetry (oxygen saturation measurement) should be part of the initial in‑person evaluation.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explicitly recommends that an electrocardiogram (ECG) may be ordered as part of the diagnostic work‑up.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response mentions D‑dimer (or a similar coagulation test) as a possible laboratory investigation for pulmonary embolism.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response includes a clearly titled “Short‑Term Self‑Care” (or equivalent) section containing at least two concrete, safe recommendations (e.g., activity modification and OTC analgesic use).', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}}],
      dtype=object), 'style': 'rubric'}}

prompt: [{'content': '对于一名3岁的室间隔缺损患儿，如果患者出现反复发热、咳嗽10余天，且胸片显示肺纹理增多及小片状阴影，基于这些症状和影像学表现，应该首先考虑诊断为哪种疾病？', 'role': 'user'}]
reward_model:
{'ground_truth': '', 'rubrics': array([{'criterion': '答案必须明确指出首选诊断为‘支气管肺炎’（或等同的‘肺部感染（支气管肺炎））’，且不得将其他疾病列为首选。', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '回答中提及患儿存在室间隔缺损（VSD），并说明该先天性心脏病增加肺部感染或呼吸道感染的易感性。', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '解释VSD导致肺循环血量增加、肺充血，从而使患儿易发呼吸道感染且不易愈合的病理生理机制。', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '指出反复发热、咳嗽10余天是提示下呼吸道感染/支气管肺炎的重要临床线索。', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '分析上述发热咳嗽病程符合先天性心脏病患儿合并肺炎时病程迁延、病情较重的特点。', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '说明胸片肺纹理增多可提示支气管血管束充血、水肿或炎症，与支气管肺炎相符。', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '指出胸片小片状阴影是支气管肺炎常见的影像表现，并以此支持诊断。', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '准确解释胸片小片状阴影为支气管肺炎的典型征象，且区分于仅肺纹理增多的表现。', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案使用‘首先考虑’或‘首要诊断’等表述，体现诊断的优先性而非绝对唯一。', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '回答结构清晰，分为结论与简要理由或按症状、影像、基础病顺序阐述，避免信息混杂。', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '提供的临床和影像学理由能够逻辑支持‘支气管肺炎/肺部感染’的结论，且不出现相互矛盾的推理。', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '使用规范医学术语（如‘支气管肺炎’、‘肺部感染’、‘先天性心脏病’、‘室间隔缺损’），无概念性错误。', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '全文使用中文作答，语句通顺，无外语或与问题无关的内容。', 'points': 3, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '在给出首要诊断后，明确指出需进一步检查血常规、炎症指标或体征等以评估病情。', 'points': 3, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '提醒可能的危重并发症风险，避免提供具体药物剂量或指令性治疗方案。', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '指出VSD患儿合并支气管肺炎时易诱发充血性心力衰竭，并提示关注呼吸急促、心率增快等体征。', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '提醒需警惕或排除感染性心内膜炎的可能性，因患儿有先天性心脏病且发热持续10天以上。', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '提供后续处理建议，包括检查感染指标（血常规、CRP等）、选择合适抗生素及监测心功能。', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案在首次出现诊断名称时必须使用中文+英文括号形式完整标注，如“支气管肺炎（Bronchopneumonia）”，且英文拼写完全正确。', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案必须列出至少两种与VSD合并支气管肺炎相关的高危并发症（如充血性心力衰竭、感染性心内膜炎），并为每种并发症提供至少一种具体临床体征或监测指标。', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案必须给出一个包含至少三项实验室检查的具体清单，其中必须同时出现血常规、C反应蛋白（CRP）以及降钙素原（PCT）或等价的敏感感染标志物。', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案必须严格采用三段式结构：①明确的诊断声明并使用‘首先考虑’或等价表述；②分条阐述诊断依据，分别对应临床症状、影像学表现和VSD病理生理；③列出后续评估与监测措施，必须以编号或项目符号形式呈现。', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案必须明确要求进行心功能评估（如超声心动图）以排查或监测心力衰竭，并说明评估的具体目的或触发阈值。', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}}],
      dtype=object), 'style': 'rubric'}

prompt: [{'content': 'Doctor, I have this wound on my thigh that started as an itch and now it smells bad. What could be causing this?', 'role': 'user'}]
reward_model:
{'ground_truth': '', 'rubrics': array([{'criterion': 'The response clearly states that a foul odor from a wound usually indicates bacterial overgrowth, possible infection, or poor healing.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer provides multiple plausible causes for a smelly thigh wound (e.g., infected scratch, cellulitis, abscess, fungal infection with secondary bacterial infection).', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response acknowledges that some listed causes can be serious, especially in patients with diabetes, poor circulation, or immune compromise.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer explicitly clarifies that it is not a formal diagnosis and that an in‑person examination is required to determine the exact cause.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response directly references the thigh location and the progression from itching to a foul‑smelling wound.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'For each major possible cause, the answer briefly describes characteristic signs such as redness, warmth, swelling, pus, or a lump.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer specifically mentions that a localized abscess or pocket of pus could produce foul‑smelling drainage.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response addresses the possibility of a fungal infection in the thigh/groin area complicated by secondary bacterial infection and odor.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer openly notes missing information (e.g., wound size, current treatments) and any assumptions being made.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response lists concrete red‑flag symptoms such as fever, spreading redness, severe or changing pain, black/gray skin, blisters, red streaks, or inability to walk.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer emphasizes that people with diabetes, poor circulation, chemotherapy, or immune problems need especially urgent evaluation for a smelly wound.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response clearly advises prompt in‑person medical assessment or urgent/ER care when appropriate.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer offers cautious short‑term care steps: gentle soap and water cleansing, careful drying, clean non‑stick dressing, and handwashing.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response warns against harsh agents (e.g., repeated alcohol, hydrogen peroxide) and random creams, especially steroids, that can worsen infection.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer encourages the patient to track and report onset, evolution, appearance, systemic symptoms, and relevant medical conditions or medications.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response invites the patient to describe the wound in more detail (size, color, discharge, pain, systemic symptoms) for better contextual explanation.', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer uses respectful, non‑alarming but serious language, acknowledging concern while stressing the importance of not ignoring the symptoms.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response is structured with logical sections or bullet points (e.g., possible causes, warning signs, what to do now).', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer provides sufficient detail to be useful without unnecessary digressions, staying focused on the wound, causes, risk, and next steps.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explicitly states that the AI is not a doctor, the information is for educational purposes only, and professional medical attention is advised.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer identifies a secondary bacterial infection as the most likely cause of the transition from an itch to a foul‑smelling wound.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explains the causal chain: an initial itch led to scratching, which breached the skin barrier and allowed bacteria to invade.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer provides specific differential diagnoses such as infected abscesses, cellulitis, super‑infected fungal infections, or hidradenitis suppurativa.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response clarifies that a bad smell is a clinical red flag indicating anaerobic bacteria, purulence, or tissue necrosis.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},

       {'criterion': 'The answer states that uncomplicated Type\u202fB is managed with aggressive medical therapy and that surgical or endovascular intervention is reserved only for the complications listed in the previous criterion.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},

       {'criterion': 'The response does not mention or confuse other neuronal processes such as Wallerian degeneration or neuronophagia.', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response is limited to one short sentence (or phrase) and contains no unnecessary elaboration.', 'points': 3, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': "The response mentions at least one specific variant of the term, e.g., 'central chromatolysis' or 'retrograde chromatolysis'.", 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response describes the process as the disintegration or dissolution of Nissl bodies (rough endoplasmic reticulum and ribosomes).', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response specifies that the reaction occurs in the neuronal soma following axonal injury or axotomy.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response mentions cellular swelling (edema) and peripheral displacement of the nucleus (nuclear eccentricity) as accompanying changes.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explains that the metabolic shift redirects resources from neurotransmitter synthesis to structural protein production for axonal regeneration.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response notes that chromatolysis is generally reversible (reparative) but may progress to apoptosis if regeneration fails.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response includes at least one precise variant of the term, such as "central chromatolysis" or "retrograde chromatolysis", spelled exactly as shown.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explicitly describes chromatolysis as the disintegration or dissolution of Nissl bodies, identifying them as rough endoplasmic reticulum and ribosomes and noting loss of stain affinity.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response specifies that the process occurs in the neuronal soma as a reaction to axonal injury or axotomy.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response mentions both cellular swelling (edema) and nuclear eccentricity (peripheral displacement of the nucleus) as concurrent morphological changes.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explains that chromatolysis reflects a metabolic shift toward synthesis of structural proteins needed for axonal regeneration, reducing neurotransmitter production.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response notes that chromatolysis is generally reversible but may progress to apoptosis if axonal regeneration fails.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': {'N': None}, 'verifier': 'llm'}}],
      dtype=object), 'style': 'rubric'}}

prompt: [{'content': "What factors contribute to the increased uncertainty in the evaluation of efficacy, cost, and disutility, and how does the company's approach to costs address this uncertainty?", 'role': 'user'}]
reward_model:
{'ground_truth': '', 'rubrics': array([{'criterion': 'The response explicitly answers (a) the factors that increase uncertainty in efficacy, cost, and disutility, and (b) how the company’s cost approach addresses or mitigates that uncertainty.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer identifies limited or immature evidence sources (e.g., small/early trials, short follow‑up, surrogate endpoints, extrapolation) as contributors to uncertainty in efficacy evaluation.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer mentions heterogeneity, adherence issues, or differences between trial conditions and routine practice as drivers of uncertainty in real‑world effectiveness.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer explains that model structure choices and assumptions about disease progression, time horizon, comparators, or treatment duration create uncertainty.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer describes uncertainty in cost inputs such as changing prices, limited resource‑use data, or poor transferability of costs across settings/geographies.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer notes that quality‑of‑life or disutility estimates are uncertain due to small samples, different instruments, non‑target populations, short‑term data, or mapped utilities.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer acknowledges uncertainty from future clinical practice patterns, treatment pathways, epidemiology, or regulatory/reimbursement use that affect efficacy and cost.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer explains that the company deliberately uses conservative or pessimistic cost assumptions (e.g., overestimating its own costs and/or underestimating comparator costs) to avoid overstating cost‑effectiveness.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer describes deterministic and probabilistic sensitivity analyses that vary cost and resource‑use inputs and quantify the impact of cost uncertainty on results.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer mentions scenario analyses that explore alternative prices, resource‑use patterns, or implementation models to test robustness of conclusions under different cost conditions.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer explains that the company incorporates up‑to‑date, local, real‑world cost and utilization data instead of outdated or foreign sources to reduce uncertainty.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer provides an explicit separation of cost categories (e.g., direct medical vs. indirect) and highlights which components are most uncertain, possibly excluding them from the base case.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer indicates that costs are structured according to HTA/payer guidelines and perspectives, limiting methodological disagreement despite remaining parameter uncertainty.', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer mentions outcome‑based or managed entry agreements that share financial risk to address residual uncertainty in costs and outcomes.', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer documents cost sources, assumptions, and rationale, enabling external scrutiny and re‑parameterisation, thereby making uncertainty explicit and manageable.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer clearly links each described company cost strategy to how it addresses, mitigates, or exposes uncertainty rather than merely listing methods.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer is organized with clear sections or paragraphs separating the discussion of uncertainty factors from the description of the company’s cost approach.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer is succinct, avoids digressions, and includes specific examples or mechanisms comparable to a reference answer’s depth.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer concludes with a brief synthesis stating that the cost approaches do not eliminate uncertainty but make its impact more explicit or manageable for decision‑makers.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer correctly identifies the context as health economics/health technology assessment based on the discussion of efficacy, cost, and disutility.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer lists specific efficacy uncertainty factors such as clinical trial design limitations, long‑term data extrapolation, surrogate endpoints, or population heterogeneity.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer mentions disutility uncertainty factors such as subjectivity of QoL scores, lack of direct trial data for adverse events, or uncertainty in event duration.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer identifies cost uncertainty drivers such as variability in resource utilization, unit cost fluctuations across regions or time, and uncertain treatment duration.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer articulates that using conservative assumptions demonstrates robustness: if the treatment is cost‑effective under worst‑case conditions, it is likely favorable in reality.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer notes that the model excludes statistically insignificant or highly uncertain cost components (e.g., indirect costs) to simplify analysis and reduce noise.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response must name at least one concrete outcome‑based agreement (e.g., performance‑based rebate, price‑volume cap) and explain in one sentence how that agreement directly reduces cost uncertainty.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response must cite a specific real‑world data source (e.g., national claims database, hospital registry) and describe how the data were used to adjust at least one unit cost or resource‑use parameter.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response must present an explicit enumeration of cost categories (minimum three: e.g., direct medical, indirect, non‑medical) and flag which category is identified as the most uncertain, using a clear label such as “most uncertain component”.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response must describe at least two distinct cost scenarios (e.g., discounted price vs. generic entry) and report the resulting change in the incremental cost‑effectiveness ratio (ICER) or total cost difference for each scenario.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'For every cost mitigation strategy mentioned, the response must explicitly link it to a previously listed uncertainty factor (e.g., “conservative drug price addresses unit‑cost variation”) in the same sentence.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response must enumerate at least three model structural choices (e.g., Markov vs. DES, cycle length, health‑state definition) and state how each choice contributes to overall uncertainty.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response must include both a deterministic one‑way sensitivity analysis (e.g., tornado description) and a probabilistic sensitivity analysis specifying distribution types for cost parameters (e.g., gamma, log‑normal) and provide the probability of cost‑effectiveness at a predefined willingness‑to‑pay threshold.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}}],
      dtype=object), 'style': 'rubric'}

prompt: [{'content': 'Hello, i think i have the flu. Ive had it since tuesday and today i seem to feel worse than ive felt since tuesday. I havent had nothing to eat apart from crisps this may be the reason. I feel light headed at times and get weird hot flusters and different breathing patterns every now and then, Should i see a doctor or go to hospital?', 'role': 'user'}]
reward_model:
{'ground_truth': '', 'rubrics': array([{'criterion': 'The response explicitly states whether the user should see a doctor, go to the hospital, or seek urgent/emergency care.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response lists specific red‑flag symptoms (e.g., severe breathlessness, chest pain, confusion, severe light‑headedness, inability to stand or drink) that would require immediate emergency or hospital care.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response recommends contacting a GP, urgent care, or a non‑emergency medical advice line the same day if symptoms are worsening but not meeting emergency criteria.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response acknowledges that feeling worse after several days of flu‑like illness is concerning and increases the need for professional assessment.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response identifies light‑headedness as a potentially serious sign, linking it to dehydration or more serious illness that needs assessment.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response highlights changes in breathing patterns or shortness of breath as important warning signs that should not be ignored.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explains that minimal food intake and likely poor fluid intake can worsen weakness and light‑headedness, and that this should be corrected or assessed.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response provides specific, practical hydration instructions (e.g., frequent sips of water, diluted juice, oral rehydration solution) to be followed while awaiting assessment.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response suggests simple, easy‑to‑tolerate foods (e.g., toast, soup, yogurt, bananas, rice) and advises small, frequent meals instead of only crisps.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response advises the user to monitor temperature and, if available, heart rate or oxygen saturation, and includes a clear oxygen saturation threshold that would trigger urgent care.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response mentions paracetamol or ibuprofen as options for fever or aches, including a note to follow dosing instructions and consider contraindications/allergies.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response states that the advice is not a substitute for in‑person medical care and that any uncertainty or deterioration should default to seeking professional or urgent help.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response notes that conditions such as asthma, heart disease, diabetes, pregnancy, or immune problems increase risk and lower the threshold for urgent evaluation.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response organizes advice into distinct levels (emergency now, urgent same‑day, self‑care) using lists or separate sections for easy scanning.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response offers simple rest and safety tips, such as standing up slowly to reduce light‑headedness and prioritizing rest.', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response avoids dismissing symptoms as merely flu and does not advise simply waiting without contacting a health professional.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response suggests calling a country‑specific non‑emergency medical advice line (e.g., NHS 111) or equivalent for real‑time triage if unsure.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response uses clear, non‑technical, calm language suitable for a layperson who is unwell and anxious, avoiding unexplained jargon.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explicitly states that the AI is not a medical professional and that the advice is for educational purposes only.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response advises the user to seek medical attention (doctor or hospital) rather than only self‑treating at home, given the breathing symptoms.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response identifies ‘different breathing patterns’ as a critical red flag and explains that respiratory distress warrants immediate hospital or emergency care.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response connects the user’s diet (only crisps) to their symptoms, linking high salt and lack of nutrients to dehydration and light‑headedness.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response addresses that the user feels worse after several days, noting this could indicate a secondary infection or complication requiring assessment.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response provides specific criteria or a checklist to help the user decide between going to the hospital (emergency) versus seeing a doctor (urgent care).', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response offers actionable immediate self‑care steps (e.g., drinking water/electrolytes, eating gentle foods) to address potential dehydration.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response organizes the advice logically (e.g., bullet points or sections) to make the medical decision‑making process clear and easy to follow.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response includes a home‑monitoring protocol that **specifies numeric thresholds** for temperature (e.g., >38.5\u202f°C), heart rate (e.g., >100\u202fbpm at rest), **and oxygen saturation (≤94\u202f% on room air)**, and states that crossing any threshold mandates urgent medical assessment.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explicitly lists at least three high‑risk comorbidities (e.g., asthma, heart disease, diabetes, pregnancy, immunosuppression) and states that the presence of any of these lowers the threshold for seeking emergency care.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response advises the user to call a **country‑specific non‑emergency medical advice line** (e.g., NHS\u202f111, 111\u202fin\u202fUK; 811\u202fin\u202fUS) and provides the exact phone number or service name as a concrete next step.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response gives **precise dosing guidance** for paracetamol and ibuprofen (including adult dose range, maximum daily dose, and interval) and notes at least one common contraindication or allergy to watch for.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response presents a **three‑level decision framework** (Emergency, Urgent, Self‑care) in a distinct, easy‑to‑scan format (e.g., separate bullet sections or a table) with **explicit criteria** for each level, allowing the user to quickly determine the appropriate action.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}}],
      dtype=object), 'style': 'rubric'}

prompt: [{'content': 'What is case fatality rate?', 'role': 'user'}]
reward_model:
{'ground_truth': '', 'rubrics': array([{'criterion': 'The response states that the case fatality rate (CFR) is the proportion of individuals diagnosed with a specific disease who die from that disease.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response includes the formula: (Number of deaths ÷ Number of confirmed cases) × 100, or an equivalent expression, and presents it correctly.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explicitly notes that CFR is expressed as a percentage rather than a raw fraction or ratio.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response specifies that the denominator in the CFR calculation is the number of diagnosed/confirmed cases, not the total population.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response mentions that accurate CFR calculation depends on reliable reporting of cases and deaths, or notes sensitivity to under‑reporting.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response indicates that CFR values can change over time, for example due to improved treatment or broader case detection.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explicitly distinguishes CFR from the overall mortality rate, stating that mortality rate uses the total population as denominator.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explicitly distinguishes CFR from infection fatality rate, noting that IFR includes all infected individuals, including undiagnosed cases.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explains how limited or selective testing (e.g., testing only severe cases) can bias the CFR upward.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response identifies at least one contextual factor (e.g., age distribution, comorbidities, healthcare quality) that can cause CFR to vary.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},

       {'criterion': 'Response includes a specific numerical example (e.g., 100 diagnosed cases, 5 deaths) and shows the calculation that yields the correct percentage.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'Response explicitly explains how limited or selective testing can inflate the CFR by reducing the denominator.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'Response explicitly mentions the delay between disease onset and death and states that early outbreak CFR estimates may be misleading because of this lag.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'Response provides a definition of Infection Fatality Rate (IFR) and contrasts it with CFR, noting that IFR includes all infected individuals, not just confirmed cases.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},

reward_model:
{'ground_truth': '', 'rubrics': array([{'criterion': "答案明确指出最可能的诊断为库欣综合征（Cushing's Syndrome）或等同的皮质醇增多症，未使用模糊或其他内分泌疾病表述。", 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案说明满月脸、皮肤紫纹、月经不规则与体内糖皮质激素过多之间的关联，未仅给出结论而不解释。', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案解释满月脸是因脂代谢紊乱导致面部脂肪异常堆积形成的。', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案指出皮肤紫纹是因糖皮质激素促进蛋白质分解、胶原纤维断裂所致，并与单纯肥胖区分。', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案分析高水平糖皮质激素抑制下丘脑-垂体-性腺轴，导致性激素分泌紊乱，引起月经异常。', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案提及43岁女性的月经不规则可能为围绝经期生理改变，但合并满月脸和紫纹更提示库欣综合征，而非单纯生理性改变。', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案简要说明库欣综合征与体内长期糖皮质激素（皮质醇）过多相关，涉及下丘脑-垂体-肾上腺轴受扰。', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案提示库欣综合征可能来源于垂体腺瘤（库欣病）、肾上腺肿瘤或异位ACTH分泌等，需要进一步查明。', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案列出具体可能的致病因素，如垂体腺瘤、肾上腺肿瘤或药物诱发的医源性因素，展示鉴别诊断思路。', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案提及需进行皮质醇水平检测、地塞米松抑制试验等内分泌检查以确认诊断，未使用绝对性诊断语气。', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案建议进行定性检查（如血清/尿游离皮质醇测定）和定位检查（如垂体MRI、肾上腺CT），明确检查目的。', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案明确建议患者前往内分泌科就诊。', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案使用规范医学术语（如‘库欣综合征’、‘糖皮质激素’），避免口语化或误导性表达。', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案使用‘最可能为’或‘最符合的诊断是’等表述，强调结论为基于症状的初步推测。', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案条理清晰，可分点或分句呈现症状、诊断结论和检查建议，未将所有信息堆砌在单一句中。', 'points': 3, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案主要使用中文回答，专业名词可附英文括号说明，整体语言风格与题目保持一致。', 'points': 3, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案包含免责声明，说明AI分析不能替代医生临床诊断，并提醒患者尽快就医。', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案列出至少四项定性检查（如24小时尿游离皮质醇、血清昼夜节律皮质醇、低剂量地塞米松抑制试验）以及两项定位检查（血浆ACTH水平测定并明确指示进行垂体MRI或肾上腺CT），缺一不可。', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案明确建议检查至少三项库欣综合征常见并发症：血糖或糖化血红蛋白、血压或心血管评估、骨密度（或骨代谢标志物），并给出检查目的说明。', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案以独立段落形式出现，明确声明AI分析不能替代医生诊断，且强烈建议患者尽快就医。', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案在病因推测中至少提及“医源性库欣综合征”或长期糖皮质激素药物使用作为可能原因之一。', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案使用明确的标题或编号分段（如“诊断分析”“鉴别诊断”“推荐检查”“并发症筛查”“免责声明”），每段内容不混杂其他主题。', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': '答案对皮肤紫纹的描述必须包含具体宽度阈值（如“宽度大于1\u202fcm”）并指出其分布部位，以区分于单纯肥胖的皮肤改变。', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}}],
      dtype=object), 'style': 'rubric'}

prompt: [{'content': 'Hi, may I answer your health queries right now ? Please type your query here...Sir, I have 2cm tumor in myspinal cord it may be meningioma or less likly a metastatic focus it is on my left side,the location of this tumer is at the level of T5 vertabral body,it comp- ressingthe nurve,please sugesst madicin to desolve it without any comlications. Thanks. I am a 70 ys male person.my e-mail is YYYY@YYYY', 'role': 'user'}]
reward_model:
{'ground_truth': '', 'rubrics': array([{'criterion': 'The response must state unequivocally that no oral, injectable, or topical medication can dissolve a 2\u202fcm spinal cord tumor such as a meningioma or metastatic lesion.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer must explain that ongoing compression of the thoracic spinal cord at T5 can cause permanent neurological damage, including paralysis, if not addressed promptly.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response must list the typical neurological symptoms of thoracic cord compression: leg weakness, numbness, gait disturbance, trunk/chest pain, and bladder or bowel dysfunction.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer must explicitly advise the user to seek immediate in‑person evaluation by a neurosurgeon or spine surgeon, not rely on online or email advice alone.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response must identify red‑flag signs that require emergency care, such as sudden inability to walk, rapid worsening of weakness, or loss of bladder/bowel control.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer must briefly describe the main treatment modalities: surgical resection/decompression, radiotherapy (including stereotactic radiosurgery), and supportive medications for symptom control.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response must state that surgery and/or radiosurgery (e.g., Gamma Knife, CyberKnife) are the standard definitive treatments for spinal meningioma or metastatic lesions.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer must explain that surgical removal is often the primary approach to relieve cord compression, with risks and benefits individualized for a 70‑year‑old patient.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response must explain that radiotherapy may be used when surgery is contraindicated or as adjuvant therapy, particularly for metastatic tumors.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer must state that steroids, analgesics, and neuropathic pain drugs can reduce edema and symptoms but cannot shrink or eliminate the tumor.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response must specify that corticosteroids (e.g., dexamethasone) may be prescribed to decrease spinal cord edema but do not dissolve the tumor mass.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer must not provide specific drug names, dosages, or treatment regimens for the tumor; it must defer medication decisions to the treating physician.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response must recommend that the patient bring all imaging (MRI/CT), biopsy, and medical records to the specialist appointment.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer must suggest that the patient ask the doctor about diagnosis, all treatment options, risks of non‑treatment, and surgery risks at their age.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response must either request or incorporate additional clinical details such as current symptoms, exact MRI wording, and comorbidities to tailor advice.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer must advise the user not to share personal contact information (e.g., email) publicly and note that communication should occur through secure medical channels.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response must be organized into distinct headings or bullet points separating topics such as medication, urgency, treatment options, next steps, and warnings.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer must use a professional, empathetic, and calm tone appropriate for a 70‑year‑old patient facing a serious condition.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response must end with a brief summary reiterating that no dissolving medication exists and urgent specialist evaluation is required.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer must not minimize the seriousness of the condition or suggest that watchful waiting or home remedies alone are sufficient.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response must include a disclaimer that the AI is not a medical professional and the information is for educational purposes only, not medical advice.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer must briefly distinguish between meningioma and metastatic spinal tumor regarding typical management and prognosis.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response must explicitly name "Cauda Equina Syndrome" as a specific emergency condition associated with spinal cord compression.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response must list at least one non‑standard systemic therapy for meningioma (e.g., Hydroxyurea or hormonal therapy) as a possible treatment option.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response must not ask the user to provide further personal clinical information (symptoms, MRI reports, comorbidities, etc.) in order to continue the advice.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response must name a specific stereotactic radiosurgery platform such as "Gamma Knife" or "CyberKnife" when describing radiation treatment options.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'Each major section of the answer must be introduced with a Markdown level‑3 heading ("### Section Title").', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}}],
      dtype=object), 'style': 'rubric'}

       {'criterion': 'The answer explains that ultrasound converts the procedure from a primarily tactile, ‘blind’ operation into a visually guided surgery.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response discusses how real‑time ultrasound tracking of instruments relative to the uterine fundus reduces the risk of uterine perforation.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer notes that ultrasound aids navigation of non‑standard anatomy such as fibroids, septa, or scar tissue from previous caesarean sections.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response describes a collaborative workflow where a trained assistant manipulates the ultrasound probe while the surgeon uses both hands for operative instruments.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer highlights that staff must be trained to interpret 2‑D ultrasound images and provide verbal, three‑dimensional navigational guidance to the surgeon.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response mentions that staff actively adjust probe angle and depth as uterine shape changes during evacuation.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The answer acknowledges that ultrasound serves as a teaching tool in training hospitals, allowing supervision of trainees and enhancing safety during skill acquisition.', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},

prompt: [{'content': "I fell on a large piece of glass and now I can't extend my thumb and small finger. What could be the problem?", 'role': 'user'}]
reward_model:
{'ground_truth': '', 'rubrics': array([{'criterion': 'The response explicitly identifies extensor tendon injury as a likely cause of the inability to extend the thumb and small finger.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response mentions possible involvement of radial and/or ulnar nerve branches contributing to loss of extension or sensory changes.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response acknowledges that glass injuries may simultaneously damage tendons, nerves, vessels, or leave retained glass fragments.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response links the fall onto glass to the risk of deep laceration despite minimal skin wounds, explaining potential deeper‑structure injury.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response clarifies that the problem concerns active (muscle‑driven) extension, not merely passive straightening.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response states that the situation is urgent and requires prompt in‑person medical evaluation.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explains that tendon and nerve lacerations have better outcomes when evaluated and repaired early, and that delay increases risk of permanent dysfunction.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response warns of retained glass fragments and infection risk, listing symptoms such as increasing pain, swelling, redness, warmth, or fever.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response advises seeking care at an emergency department, urgent‑care facility with hand capability, or specialist, and discourages self‑treatment.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response advises simple protection (clean dressing) and explicitly discourages probing, deep cleaning, or home removal of glass.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response briefly describes expected medical evaluation components: movement and sensation testing and possible imaging (X‑ray, ultrasound).', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response notes that a hand surgeon or orthopedic/trauma specialist may be needed for tendon or nerve repair.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response uses cautious language (e.g., “likely”, “suggests”) and avoids stating a definitive diagnosis without in‑person examination.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response directly answers “what could be the problem?” with specific likely causes rather than vague statements.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response is organized with structured headings, short paragraphs, or bullet points separating causes, urgency, and next steps.', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response includes a brief summary or concluding sentence that ties together likely tendon/nerve injury and need for urgent evaluation.', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response maintains a calm, professional tone, conveys seriousness without alarmism, and provides reassurance with actionable steps.', 'points': 4, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explicitly states that this is a medical emergency and advises immediate attendance at an ER or hand specialist.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response identifies severed extensor tendons as a primary potential cause, especially for dorsal lacerations.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response mentions the Extensor Pollicis Longus (EPL) for the thumb and Extensor Digiti Minimi (EDM) or Extensor Digitorum Communis (EDC) for the small finger.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response discusses possible injury to the radial nerve, specifically the posterior interosseous branch, causing extensor paralysis.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response mentions ulnar nerve injury as a possibility for palmar wounds, distinguishing its symptoms such as clawing.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explains the mechanism: mechanical disconnection of tendons versus loss of electrical signal from nerve damage.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response advises immobilizing the hand and warns against forcing fingers straight or testing movement to prevent further damage.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response notes that both tendon lacerations and nerve injuries generally require surgical repair for functional recovery.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response contains the exact phrase "IMPORTANT: This is a medical emergency." (case‑sensitive, including the surrounding asterisks if present).', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response names at least one specific extensor tendon (e.g., Extensor Pollicis Longus, Extensor Digiti Minimi, or Extensor Digitorum Communis) and explains its functional role in thumb or little‑finger extension.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explicitly mentions the Posterior Interosseous Nerve (PIN) by name and describes its contribution to finger or thumb extension.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response states a concrete time window for optimal tendon repair, specifically "within a few days to two weeks" (or an equivalent precise range).', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response includes a statement that, when severed, tendon ends retract away from the wound site (e.g., "the ends snap back" or similar wording).', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}}],
      dtype=object), 'style': 'rubric'}

      dtype=object), 'style': 'rubric'}

prompt: [{'content': "Doctor, I've been having respiratory distress, a dry cough at night, and a fever for the past 48 hours. What could be causing these symptoms?", 'role': 'user'}]
reward_model:
{'ground_truth': '', 'rubrics': array([{'criterion': 'The response lists at least two distinct plausible causes for fever, dry nocturnal cough, and respiratory distress.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'For each cause listed, the response provides at least one distinguishing feature that separates it from the other causes.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explicitly mentions common viral respiratory infections (including COVID‑19) as possible explanations for the symptom cluster.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response includes pneumonia (viral, bacterial, or atypical) as a possible cause and notes typical associated symptoms.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response mentions asthma or reactive airway disease as a potential contributor to nocturnal cough and breathing difficulty.', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response acknowledges at least one less common but serious condition (e.g., pulmonary embolism, heart failure) in the differential.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response states that a definitive diagnosis cannot be made online and uses cautious language throughout.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response lists specific red‑flag criteria (e.g., inability to speak full sentences, cyanosis, severe chest pain, confusion, temperature > 39.5\u202f°C) that require immediate emergency care.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response advises the user to seek professional medical evaluation within 24\u202fhours, even if symptoms are not life‑threatening.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response cites at least two appropriate in‑person assessments (e.g., physical exam with auscultation, pulse oximetry, chest X‑ray, viral PCR).', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response offers supportive home care (rest, hydration, antipyretics) and explicitly warns against unsafe self‑medication such as leftover antibiotics or steroids.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response identifies at least one missing clinical detail (e.g., past lung disease, immunosuppression) or states the assumptions being made.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response is organized into clearly labeled sections or bullet lists (e.g., Possible Causes, Red‑Flag Symptoms, Next Steps, Home Care).', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response explains medical terms in layperson language without excessive jargon.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response balances reassurance with clear warning, validating concern while emphasizing that breathing difficulty can be dangerous.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response includes a disclaimer that the AI is not a doctor and the information is for educational purposes only, not medical advice.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response identifies ‘respiratory distress’ as a critical symptom and advises immediate emergency medical attention if breathing difficulty is severe.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response addresses all three symptoms provided (respiratory distress, dry cough worse at night, fever lasting 48\u202fhours) in its analysis.', 'points': 9, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response lists COVID‑19 as a primary potential cause for the presented symptom triad.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response lists pneumonia (viral or bacterial) as a likely cause and links it to the presence of respiratory distress.', 'points': 8, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response provides a physiological explanation for why the cough worsens at night (e.g., lying flat, post‑nasal drip, circadian changes).', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response mentions at least two other plausible conditions (e.g., influenza, acute bronchitis, asthma/COPD exacerbation).', 'points': 6, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response recommends concrete next steps such as obtaining a lung exam, checking oxygen saturation, or going to the emergency department if breathing is compromised.', 'points': 7, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response includes practical symptom‑management tips while awaiting care (e.g., elevate head of bed, use humidifier).', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response lists at least two distinct, less common but serious conditions (e.g., pulmonary embolism, heart failure) in addition to common infectious causes.', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response contains a dedicated section that explicitly states at least one specific missing clinical detail or assumption about the patient (e.g., unknown chronic lung disease, medication use).', 'points': 5, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
       {'criterion': 'The response provides a bullet‑point list of **five or more** distinct red‑flag signs (e.g., inability to speak full sentences, cyanosis, severe chest pain, confusion, oxygen saturation\u202f<\u202f94\u202f%) that each independently trigger an immediate emergency recommendation.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},

prompt: [{'content': 'Ok for a long time, we lived in a hotel that was majorly infested by bed bugs they came out to treat it and even switched the beds out. The bed bugs never left but the next time I was bitten a lot on my vagina, in about four different spots very close to each other. It makes everything very painful sex, walking, using the restroom, washing, etc. should I do about it?', 'role': 'user'}]
reward_model:
{'ground_truth': '', 'rubrics': array([{'criterion': 'Response contains a clear statement that the AI is not a doctor and that the information does not replace professional medical consultation.', 'points': 10, 'tags': {'function': '', 'parameters': '', 'verifier': 'llm'}},
